maml:description.maml:para: Get command details for DiskReportingTools
Use this command to get a brief summary of commands in the DiskReportingTools module. The command will return a list of commands with their names, aliases, and a brief description.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-DiskReportingTools
ModuleName: DiskReportingTools [v0.12.0]
Name Alias Synopsis ---- ----- -------- Get-DiskReportingTools Get command details for DiskReportingTools. Get-RecycleBinSize rbsz Get recycle bin size New-HtmlDriveReport Create a drive HTML report Show-DriveUsage sdu Display a colorized graph of disk usage Show-DriveView sdv Display a summary view of all drives. Show-FolderUsage sfu Show folder usage by file extension.

dev:remarks.maml:para: The output only shows exported commands. Users on non-Windows platforms will get a different set of commands.

maml:description.maml:para: Get recycle bin size
Use this command to get the size of the recycle bin on a computer. The command will return size information for each drive found.
Specify the name of a remote computer
Specify an alternate credential.
Specify the name of a remote computer
Specify an alternate credential.

command:example.dev:code:

Computername: SRV1

maml:description.maml:para: Display a colorized graph of disk usage

This command uses the PowerShell console to display a colorized graph of disk usage. The graph will be color coded depending on the amount of free disk space. By default the command will display all fixed drives but you can limit output to a single drive.
This command writes an object to the pipeline, but the properties are ANSI formatted strings.
The name of the drive to check, including the colon. See examples. This parameter is only supported on Windows.
The name of the computer to query. This command has aliases of: CN This parameter is only supported on Windows.
Specify an alternate credential. This parameter is only supported on Windows.
Display raw output without formatting.
The name of the drive to check, including the colon. See examples. This parameter is only supported on Windows.
The name of the computer to query. This command has aliases of: CN This parameter is only supported on Windows.
Specify an alternate credential. This parameter is only supported on Windows.
Display raw output without formatting.

dev:remarks.maml:para: The output would be colored blocks for drives C: and D:, yellow for F: and green for E:

maml:description.maml:para: Display a summary view of all drives

This command will display a summary view of all local, fixed drives. The default behavior is to send the output to Out-GridView. But if you are running PowerShell 7 and have the Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleGuiTools module installed, you can use the dynamic ConsoleGridView parameter.
The name of a remote computer.
Specify the grid title.
Specify an alternate credential.
Display raw output without formatting.
The name of a remote computer.
Specify the grid title.
Specify an alternate credential.
Display raw output without formatting.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will show all drives on the local computer in an Out-GridView.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-Content C:\scripts\company.txt | Show-DriveView -Title "Company Servers" -cgv

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the server names from a text file and pipe them to Show-DriveView. This example is using the parameter alias for the dynamic parameter ConsoleGridView. This implies a PowerShell 7 environment with the Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleGuiTools module installed. The output will be a ConsoleGridView window with the title "Company Servers".

maml:description.maml:para: Show folder usage by file extension

Use this command to show folder usage by file extension. The default output is a color formatted display of extensions showing a percentage of the total folder size. The output is limited to files that meet a minimum threshold percentage of the total folder size. The default threshold is 5%. You can change this value with the -Threshold parameter.
Specify the path to the folder to analyze. Use a full file system path. The path will be searched recursively.
Specify the name of a remote computer. You must have admin rights. The default is the localhost. This is a dynamic parameter and only available on Windows platforms.
Specify an alternate credential for the remote computer. This is a dynamic parameter and only available on Windows platforms.
Display raw output without formatting.
Specify the minimum percentage to display. The default is 5%
Sort the graphical output by size or extension name in ascending order.
Sort the graphical output in descending order.
Specify the path to the folder to analyze. Use a full file system path. The path will be searched recursively.
Specify the name of a remote computer. You must have admin rights. The default is the localhost. This is a dynamic parameter and only available on Windows platforms.
Specify an alternate credential for the remote computer. This is a dynamic parameter and only available on Windows platforms.
Display raw output without formatting.
Specify the minimum percentage to display. The default is 5%
Sort the graphical output by size or extension name in ascending order.
Sort the graphical output in descending order.

dev:remarks.maml:para: The output will be color formatted and styled. The number in the graph is the number of files for each extension.

maml:description.maml:para: Show folder usage by file age

Use this command to show folder usage by file age. The default aging criteria is based on the LastWriteTime property, but you can use the CreationTime property instead. The default output is a color formatted display of extensions showing a percentage of the total folder size.
The assumption is that you will process a folder with many files.
Specify the path to the folder to analyze. Use a full file system path. The path will be searched recursively.
Specify the name of a remote computer. You must have admin rights. The default is the localhost. This is a dynamic parameter and will only be available on Windows PowerShell.
specify an alternate credential. This is a dynamic parameter and will only be available on Windows
Specify the file aging property.
Display raw output without formatting.
Specify the name of a remote computer. You must have admin rights. The default is the localhost. This is a dynamic parameter and will only be available on Windows PowerShell.
specify an alternate credential. This is a dynamic parameter and will only be available on Windows
Specify the path to the folder to analyze. Use a full file system path. The path will be searched recursively.
Specify the file aging property.
Display raw output without formatting.

dev:remarks.maml:para: The default output will be a color formatted bar chart. The number in the graph is the number of files for each aging group.
